intro: Omphalocarpum radlkoferi var. pluriloculare, commonly known as the many-ovary burrweed, is a species of flowering plant in the family Fabaceae. It is native to parts of southern Africa, particularly South Africa, where it thrives in arid and semi-arid environments. The plant is characterized by its unique, spiny, multi-locular pods that encase its seeds, which are adapted for dispersal by attachment to animals or clothing. Its small, trifoliate leaves and yellow flowers are typical of the legume family, and it often grows in disturbed soils or along roadsides. The botanical features of this plant make it an important component of its native ecosystem, though it can be considered a weed in some agricultural settings.
